title: Z
summary: A couple is shaken to the core when their eight-year-old son begins hanging out with a creepy and ominous imaginary friend.
critic_reviews: Once Z digs its nails into trauma in the film’s final act, the proceedings get complex, bizarre, and wildly messy.

Z provides effective scares and at least one moment that made this parent scream in horror. It’s doing so many of the right things, but like a puzzle with a few pieces missing, it’s hard to see the full picture.
Z’s greatest virtue is in the delivery of its frights, which hit like a slap in the face despite falling into the general category of “jump scares.”
It’s one of those films that may be overly reliant on jump scares when you tally them all up, but I’d by lying if I didn’t admit that a few of them legitimately made me jump.

reviews.content: There are moments in this film that shocked me on a new level. It build suspense brilliantly but like many films it feels rushed towards the end. It also takes a lot of ideas from the Babadook.  Definitely recommend though

A Shudder original, so I wasn't expecting much.In all honesty I thought it was better than some horror stuff that was released this year but there's nothing worth mentioning and I say this because even though there's some interestingA Shudder original, so I wasn't expecting much.In all honesty I thought it was better than some horror stuff that was released this year but there's nothing worth mentioning and I say this because even though there's some interesting elements, the way it's driven makes the jump scares an abusive resource for the narrative and I hate when that happens.
The script has creativity, maybe even in the name of the thing or maybe not.
